Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Arithmetic and Geometry of Pure and Mixed Shimura Varieties
Award.AbstractNarration:
A central theme in modern number theory is the conjectural relations between classes of automorphic representations and Galois representations, with notions of algebraicity on both sides, in the context of Langlands program and its p-adic and p-torsion analogues. To realize such conjectural relations at all, most known methods so far involve the use of the cohomology of certain algebraic varieties and their models over the integers; namely, the so-called (pure) Shimura varieties, the Kuga families over them (generalizing the Kuga--Sato varieties over modular curves) which are special cases of the so-called mixed Shimura varieties, their compactifications, and good models of these over the integers. The research projects in this proposal aim at making further progress in understanding such fundamentally important geometric objects, through extensive studies along directions both old and new, and at developing their new arithmetic applications.

Number theory and geometry are the two oldest branches of mathematics, and combined applications of them (such as error-correcting codes) have become indispensable in modern daily life (involving, for example, telecommunication and data storage). The pure and mixed Shimura varieties are important geometric objects relating algebra, analysis, and geometry in natural yet mysterious ways, and advances in their theory have contributed to many exciting recent developments in number theory. The education projects in this proposal aim at creating a vertically integrated learning environment for number theory and arithmetic geometry at the University of Minnesota, from which students at all levels can benefit, including supports for outreach activities, summer learning projects, and the development of courses and learning seminars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pure and mxied Shimura varieties are generalizations of the classical modular curves and the families of elliptic curves over them, whose arithmetic and geometry has played important roles in modern number theory.

The most important and novel outcomes of this project, in terms of its intellectual merits, can be summarized as follows:

(1) With Michael Harris, Richard Taylor, and Jack Thorne, we found a new way to associate Galois representations with automorphic representations, without any self-duality assumption.  One key ingredient is a new p-adic geometric construction of Eisenstein classes in certain rigid cohomology of the ordinary loci of Shimura varieties, based on my previous works.  This is a major breakthrough in Langlands program, and has inspired important works such as Scholze's groundbreaking generalization for torsion cohomology classes.

For nonexperts, the upshot is as follows:  The association of Galois representations with automorphic representations can be viewed as a vast generalization of the quadratic reciprocity law.  Many earlier works made use of the so-called etale cohomology of Shimura varieties, but Galois representations associated with non-self-dual automorphic representations are not supposed to occur this way.  Our method overcame this difficulty by realizing the desired Galois representations as p-adic limits of those that do occur in the etale cohomology, by using some kind of boundary part of the rigid cohomology of ordinary loci.

(2) To study Galois representations on the etale cohomology of Shimura varieties, it is important to understand their restrictions to decomposition groups.  For proper Shimura varieties, these are isomorphic to the cohomology of the associated nearby cycles over the proper reductions, by the proper base change theorem.  With Stroh, based on a series of works on integral models of toroidal compactifications by myself and by Madapusi Pera, we showed that this common assumption of properness is redundant for essentially all integral models of Shimura varieties people constructed in the literature, including all cases of PEL, Hodge, and abelian types studied by myself, Kisin, and Madapusi Pera.  As a result, we can readily generalize a lot of important works to the nonproper case, such as Mantovan's formula relating the cohomology of Shimura varieties, Rapoport--Zink spaces, and Igusa varieties; and such as Scholze's formula for the Langlands--Kottwitz method.

For nonexperts, the upshot is as follows:  By analyzing the geometry of the reductions of Shimura varieties, people have already obtained a lot of important results for the nearby cycles.  But they used to have to impose the properness assumption in order to relate the results back to results about the etale cohomology of Shimura varieties, because only the latter are directly related to automorphic forms.  Our results provide a replacement of the proper base change theorem in all cases people need.

(3) With Stroh, we formulated a precise notion of well-positioned subschemes of integral models of Shimura varieties, which include as special cases the familiar p-rank, Newton, Ekedahl--Oort, and Kottwitz--Rapoport strara and all Oort central leaves; and constructed partial toroidal and minimal compactifications for all of them, with familiar boundary stratifications and formal local properties, as if they were compactifications of the whole Shimura varieties.  We then generalize to this context Koecher's principal and the relative vanishing for cohernet automorphic bundles, and Pink's and Morel's formulae for direct images and middle perversity extensions of etale sheaves.

For nonexperts, the upshot is as follows:  The boundary cohomology of Shimura varieties has played more and more important roles in recent years, and our results provide a way to study the analogue for the cohomology of many meaningful subschemes of the reductions of Shimura varieties.  For example, such an idea has played an important role in the generalization of Caraiani and Scholze's vanishing results to the noncompact case.

(4) With Hansheng Diao, Ruochuan Liu, and Xinwen Zhu, we have developed a p-adic analogue of Deligne's Riemann--Hilbert correspondence, and also obtained de Rham and Hodge--Tate comparison isomorphisms for the etale cohomology, for all smooth varieties with nontrivial coefficients, generalizing Scholze's results in the proper smooth case (and many important earlier works since Faltings).

For nonexperts, the upshot is as follows:  To have any meaningful comparison between the p-adic etale cohomology and the de Rham cohomology with nontrivial coefficients, there needs to be a comparison between etale local systems and connections, and the lack of properness is a major source of difficulty.  We overcame this by introducing log geometry into Scholze's p-adic analytic geometric framework and, rather crucially, by finding a way to calculate the residues and ensure that the log objects compare well with each other.

As for the broader impacts, I supervised 26 undergraduate projects, two graduate students, and one postdoc.  I organized two workshops and gave numerous lectures, including many instructional ones with young audiences.  Notable outcomes include an example-based introduction to Shimura varieties and several survey articles.  All my results are publicly available on my website.
